definition:
A [*discrete valuation*]{} on a field $K$ is a valuation
$|\cdot|: K \to {\mathbb{R}}$ whose image is a discrete subset of
${\mathbb{R}}$.

For any field $K$ with a discrete valuation $|\cdot|$, the set
$$R := \{x \in K : |x| \leq 1\}$$ is a subring of $K$ with sole maximal
ideal $$M := \{x \in K : |x| < 1\},$$ and hence $R$ is a discrete
valuation ring. Conversely, given any discrete valuation ring $R$, the
field of fractions $K$ of $R$ admits a discrete valuation sending each
element $x \in R$ to $c^n$, where $0 < c < 1$ is some arbitrary fixed
constant and $n$ is the order of $x$, and extending multiplicatively to
$K$.

[**Note:**]{} Discrete valuations are often written additively instead
of multiplicatively; under this alternate viewpoint, the element $x$
maps to $\log_c|x|$ (in the above notation) instead of just $|x|$. This
transformation reverses the order of the absolute values (since
$c < 1$), and sends the element $0 \in K$ to $\infty$. It has the
advantage that every valuation can be normalized by a suitable scalar
multiple to take values in the integers.
